awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Determination of the Structure and Properties of Microfibrillated Cellulose during Dynamic Phase Transitions
awd_abstract_narration:
Microfibrillated cellulose (MFC) is a waste product generated during paper manufacturing.  It is processed commercially for some industrial uses, but it also has a potential application as a rheological modifier in consumer, fabric and home care products.  Rheological modifiers are materials added to certain products to customize their flow behavior.  MFC is non-ionic, which makes it compatible with a wide range of product recipes, but it must be dispersed throughout a product to modify the product's properties.  The challenge is that MFC is supplied as a concentrated slurry of highly entangled fibers in water that are difficult to disperse in most products.  This GOALI project, which is a collaboration between Lehigh University and Procter and Gamble, will investigate how the structure of MFC depends on parameters such as the temperature, composition of the host solution and forces exerted on MFC due to flow.  Using several techniques that probe the microstructural arrangements of the MFC fibers, the researchers explore transitions in the microstructure that can enhance dispersal of MFC in useful products.  Repurposing MFC waste from the paper industry as additives for consumer products will reduce the need for MFC disposal and reduce manufacturing costs of valuable consumer products.  The research team will engage in a variety of outreach activities, including programs at the Da Vinci Science Center to educate the public in colloids and rheology, mentoring middle school and high school students interested in STEM fields, and training undergraduate and graduate students in research.

The overall goal of this GOALI project is to characterize the spatial and temporal rheological evolution of an MFC scaffold to enable its use as a rheological modifier for consumer, fabric and home care products. MFC has a fiber size that is comparable to the fiber size of rheological modifiers in current use, but unlike other modifiers, MFC has negligible charge on the colloid. The potential advantages of MFC will be explored by characterizing the microstructural evolution of MFC using microrheology and microscopy, by characterizing the evolution of bulk rheology of MFC systems, and by determining equilibrium properties and scaffold structure after phase transitions using a unique microfluidic platform and multiple particle tracking microrheology.  MFC solutions will be characterized during phase transitions due to three driving forces: temperature, changes in the surrounding solution and flow-induced mechanical forces. This knowledge will enable the use of these materials as rheological modifiers for the formulated product industry. The results of the research will identify materials that lead to homogeneous MFC suspensions and determine the microstructure and macroscopic structure and properties that lead to stable suspensions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: The overall goal of this work is to characterize the structure and rheology of microfibrillated cellulose (MFC) to determine whether it can be used as a rheological modifier for products, including consumer, fabric and home care products. Rheological modifiers are materials added to products that change material flow, feel and induce phase transitions. For example, shampoo would be a water-like solution unless rheological modifiers are added to enable facile handling by consumers. This work focuses on the use of MFC from wood, a colloidal fiber, as a rheological modifier with the goal of repurposing MFC from paper waste into new products. MFC is of particular interest due to the non-ionic surface of the colloid, which enables surface modification and incorporation into a wide variety of formulations. 

Currently, little is known about MFC structure and rheology and the impact on final properties and stability. Our approach uses a combination of bulk rheology, multiple particle tracking microrheology (MPT) and microscopy to characterize the evolution of the scaffold microstructure and properties during phase transitions induced by an external driving force. Overall, this work addresses the industrial need to repurpose a waste product from one industry to be processed for use in new industries, specifically as a rheological modifier. This work is also a fundamental study of fibrous colloidal gels, providing both techniques and analysis of dynamic changes of these types of systems.

In this work we modify the surface of MFC by making the colloid negatively charged, oxidized MFC (OMFC), and thermoresponsive. Results for OMFC show that the structure and rheology of the material varies with the stability of the starting colloidal solution. The more stable the solution the more ideal the structure when the material undergoes gelation induced by surfactants. This is key information in the use of these colloids in products that evolve during end-use, such as dishwashing and laundry pods. These materials also undergo length-scale dependent rearrangement during gelation. Information on the dynamic pore structure and size provides vital information about the size and type of molecules that OMFC can encapsulate and release.

Key results from characterization of thermoresponsive MFC are: (1) the material structure is based on the initial colloidal solution structure prior to gelation and (2) during thermal cycles the structure and properties of the material are not completely reversible. Defining the structure of the material by the initial concentration will enable the design of products where structure and stiffness are specified either by packaging, consumer or other industrial requirements. Reversibility of properties during dynamic phase transitions is likely due to the history of the material structure and kinetics of the thermoresponsive polymer grafted onto the MFC. Phase transitions occur at the temperature the polymer changes confirmation which indicates that the structure and behavior of thermoresponsive MFC is set by the polymer grafted onto the surface, This will enable tuning of these parameters during product development.

Overall, this work will inform the design of either new products or products that are replacing colloids that are presently made for rheological modification with a waste colloid, MFC. This works is foundational in the industrial shift to using MFC and the close collaboration between the PI at Purdue University and Co-Is at Procter and Gamble Co. (P&G) enable practical development of this material for incorporation into a wide variety of products.  

Broader impacts: The goals of the combined research and education effort of this proposal are to: 1) determine the potential of a waste product, MFC, as a rheological modifier for industrial applications and (2) educate a broad audience about rheology, colloids and engineering. Key results from the broader impacts are: (1) dissemination of results in peer-reviewed papers, conference presentations and to scientists at P&G, (2) mentoring of graduate and undergraduate students and (3) outreach to middle school students. The proposed work has resulted in 4 manuscripts (3 published and 1 submitted). A fifth manuscript is drafted and being edited for submission. This work has also been presented at several conferences by the PI and two PhD students that have been funded by this grant. One PhD student has made several trips to P&G and presented this work to a broad audience at the company. During these trips, the student also learned new techniques from scientists at P&G and taught these scientists how to make the materials used in this work. Exchange of ideas between Purdue and P&G occur monthly by telecommunication. Additionally, five undergraduate students have contributed to this project. 

The PI was also an active participation in a program developed to get middle school students excited about STEM. Through this work, the PI developed experiments highlighting complex fluids and did these with the students. This program is successful in engaging these students and encouraging them to become future scientists and engineers.
